content.webTitle: CD: Lutyens: Présages; String Trio; Fantasie Trio; Motet, etc

fields.headline: Lutyens: Présages; String Trio; Fantasie Trio; Motet, etc, Endymion/ Exaudi/ Weeks
fields.bodyText: The centenary of Elisabeth Lutyens's birth this year has been passing almost unnoticed, just as her stature in British music went unappreciated for much of her composing career. This mixture of a cappella choral and instrumental works from the 1950s and 1960s is a timely and beautifully performed tribute. It ranges from the Motet of 1953, in which Lutyens sets a text from Wittgenstein's Tractatus, to Verses of Love from 1970, whose settings of poems by Ben Jonson show her moving away from the 12-note technique that she had so single-mindedly employed since the second world war. If none of the pieces here ranks among Lutyens's very greatest - CD reissues of some of those are badly needed - they are all fine examples of her powerfully concentrated style, from a period in which her language was at its most pungent and highly-wrought, whether in the keening monodies of the solo oboe Présages, or the patchworks and mosaics of the Webernesque String Trio and the Fantasie Trio, for flute, clarinet and piano.
